awd_titl_txt: An Experimental Investigation of the Formation of Complex Organic Molecules in Interstellar Analog Ices
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will investigate the formation of complex organic molecules (COMs) containing carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen atoms on ice analog samples resembling interstellar ices.  To study this problem, the investigators will perform laboratory experiments on ice analogs at conditions mimicking the environment of interstellar space, viz. ultra-high vacuum, low temperatures, and exposure to ultraviolet radiation.  Results from the study will allow astronomers to understand how certain key COMs are formed on ices within interstellar clouds and the processes that generate molecular complexity in space.  This project will provide training in advanced laboratory astrophysics to graduate and undergraduate students, including ones from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM.  The team will also give popular science lectures at local high schools, enabling educators to incorporate research into teaching and attract students to pursue STEM careers.

The research team will explore the synthesis of key classes of COMs – aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, esters, and amides – on interstellar ice analogs.  They will do so by exposing interstellar ice analog samples to Lyman alpha radiation in a low-temperature, ultra-high vacuum space simulation chamber.  The molecules produced in the experiment will be characterized in a highly complementary manner using infrared, Raman, and ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, as well as mass spectrometry.  The measurements will yield reliable reaction rates and branching fractions necessary to accurately interpret astronomical observations of COMs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to experimentally produce and identify novel complex organic molecules (COMs)—organic molecules containing >6 atoms of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen—and new reaction pathways in an innovative ultra-high vacuum space simulation chamber. The chemistry of interstellar ices was explored via the interactions of ionizing radiation with interstellar ice analog samples to understand constraints on the level of molecular complexity that can ultimately be synthesized in the interstellar medium (ISM). These objectives were achieved by replicating the physical and chemical conditions of ice-coated interstellar grains in a next-generation surface science instrument through the exposure of interstellar ice analog samples resembling ices in cold molecular clouds as well as in low- and high-mass star-forming regions at astrophysically relevant temperatures (10–50 K) to proxies for proxies for galactic cosmic rays. We have implemented new methods and techniques to facilitate the synthesis of COMs online and in situ via spectroscopic detection schemes from the far infrared to ultraviolet regions of the spectrum. During temperature programmed desorption (TPD), vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) photoionization reflectron mass spectrometry (PI-ReTOF-MS) has proven to be an indispensable tool in the identification of chemical species, many of which are inaccessible to benchtop chemistry. These cutting-edge techniques have repeatedly demonstrated their utility, such as in the production and detection of molecular species entirely new to experimental chemistry.

The sensitivity afforded by the PI-ReTOF-MS technique has led to the observation of several new species produced by thermal reactions in model interstellar ices. Collaboration with computational quantum chemists in tandem with isotopic labelling experiments has allowed the mechanism of these reactions to be better understood as originating from quantum tunnelling. While thermal formation of observed species 1-aminoethanol (CH3CH(OH)NH2), ethanimine (CH3CHNH), and methoxyethanol (CH3OCH(OH)CH3) are known, it is only now known that quantum tunneling is responsible for their formation. Large molecules and chelation agents like 1-(1-hydroxyethylamino)ethanol (NH(CH3CH(OH))2) and 1-ethylideneaminoethanol (CH3CH(OH)NCHCH3) were recently reported for the first time after their identification in these thermally processed ices.

By studying ices irradiated with proxies for galactic cosmic rays (GCRs), more information can be gathered about chemical reactions requiring initiation. The simplified composition of the model ices, which are typically binary, aids in determining the reaction mechanism—radical-radical recombination—responsible for the presence of many species. Of the molecules reported here, some have also been detected in the ISM by observational astronomers: acetone (CH3COCH3), propanal (CH3CH2CHO), propylene oxide (CH3(c-CHCH2O), hydroxyacetone (CH3COCH2OH), methyl acetate (CH3COOCH3), and acetamide (NH2COCH3). These laboratory experiments have revealed the likely presence of a large number of previously undetected or even previously unknown molecules in the ISM. Other stable molecules detected include 3-hydroxypropanal (HOCH2CH2CHO), glycolic acid (HOCH2COOH), the monomethyl ester of carbonic acid (CH3OCOOH), and glycinal (NH2CH2CHO)—the amino-aldehyde form of glycine (NH2CH2COOH), the simplest proteinogenic amino acid—have also been detected in the laboratory and are expected to be present in astrophysical ices. but have yet to be detected in the ISM.

Less stable molecules have also been regularly detected; the high energy initiation provided by GCR proxies is capable of triggering tautomeric reactions in which an aldehyde or ketone can be converted into an enol (alkene-alcohol). This alternative method of synthesis takes advantage of unimolecular reactions and appears to be an efficient mechanism toward the production of high-energy molecules. Enols detected include 1,1-ethenediol (CH2=C(OH)2), propen-1-ol (CH3CH=CHOH), propen-2-ol (CH2=C(OH)CH3), propene-1,2-diol (CH3C(OH)=CHOH), 2-propene-1,2-diol (CH2=C(OH)CH2OH), 1-methoxyethenol (CH2C(OH)OCH3), and propene-1,3-diol (HOCH2CH=CHOH). Not only does the number of hydroxyl groups on these species demonstrate the beginnings of abiotic sugar formation, but these are also all structurally and energetically similar to 1,2-ethenediol (HOCH2CH2OH), an intermediate in aldol condensation reactions used biologically to form sugars and amino acids. The most densely hydroxylated, and therefore possibly least stable molecule detected in the course of these investigations is methanediol (CH2(OH)2), which has been reported alongside other geminally-substituted methanes aminomethanol (NH2CH2OH) and methanediamine (CH2(NH2)2). Other molecules that have been detected in PI-ReTOF-MS experiments, have been previously described as ‘impossible’ or ‘non-existent’. However, the sensitivity provided by this instrumentation has led to the first-ever detection of isolated methanediamine and long-elusive oxirene (c-OCHCH).

These experiments have repeatedly shown that astrophysical ices are an ideal environment for the production and preservation of the chemical prerequisites for the Origins of Life. The abundance of biorelevant chemicals discussed here further underscores the importance of understanding the chemical evolution of the ISM not only because of its role in the development of life on Earth, but because of the access to new and exotic chemistry that laboratory astrochemistry and the study of astrophysical ices enables.
